Award.AwardTitle: SoCS: Tipping Collective Action in Social Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of the challenges facing contemporary society, such as emission reductions or vaccination for infectious diseases, are collective action problems. To address these challenges, new approaches are needed to understand, stimulate and sustain collective action in large heterogeneous populations. To promote cooperative behavior at large scales, this project will develop computational tools to facilitate the context for cooperation - homogeneity, effective communication - observed in smaller scale case studies and field experiments. The investigators will test new ways to increase collective action using mobile applications and social media.

The project will use controlled decision-making experiments to test whether contributions to collective action can be increased by providing the right messages to the right people, such that cooperative behavior can cascade through a social network. Empirical research has shown that individuals are more likely to participate in collective action if they expect others like them to participate. Experiments will be performed in online social networks of students at Arizona State University to test the proposed approach to actualizing collective action within the university community. Data from the experiments will be used to develop mathematical models of collective action in social networks.

Broader impacts: The research will lead to new theoretical frameworks for understanding collective action and provide concrete tools to apply these insights. Insights about what kind of feedback to whom is most effective for increasing collective action may make social media a potential effective policy tool for organizations. Potentially, the project will have societal impact by promoting collective action in important areas such as healthcare, voter participation, and energy conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many of the challenges facing contemporary society, such as pollution reductions or vaccination for infectious diseases, are collective action problems.  To address these challenges, new approaches are needed to understand, stimulate and sustain collective action in large heterogeneous populations. To promote cooperative behavior at large scales, this project developed computational tools to study how to stimulate large scale cooperation. Effective cooperation has been observed in smaller scale case studies of rather isolated homogenous communities. The investigators aimed to test new ways to increase collective action in large-scale heterogeneous populations using online communities.

The project used controlled decision-making experiments to test whether contributions to collective action can be increased by providing the right messages to the right people, such that cooperative behavior can cascade through a social network. Empirical research had shown that individuals are more likely to participate in collective action if they expect others like them to participate. Experiments were performed online at a large university. We found, in contrast to earlier studies, that the effect of social influence were minimal in stimulating cooperation.

We also studied online communities and collected data from millions of users via data mining of publicly available data of online communities, such as Stack Exchange. We found that successful online communities have twice the number of participants doing small quick tasks compared to difficult tasks. This indicates that a sufficient diverse menu of tasks is needed for online communities to attract and retain users to make them successful. We used the data from online communities to develop mathematical and computational models. Those modeling activities demonstrate the importance of recruitment for online communities to be successful. Successful communities are able to harvest the attention of a large enough population who are foraging for tasks online, to sustain a sufficient flow of activities which attract more visitors.

The research has helped us to advice various start-ups who aim to create and foster online communities to stimulate collective action related to sustainability goals in the physical world. They experience many challenges in doing so, especially in getting enough attention. Integration with common platforms like Facebook and Twitter is a requirement for those companies if they want to sustain contributions.
